Transformations

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
nodoc = [c for n,c in vars(pd.DataFrame).items() if callable(c) and not n.startswith('_') and c.__doc__ is None]
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

DataFrame.repetitions[source]

DataFrame.repetitions(col)

Counts the number of repetitions for each element.

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df = pd.DataFrame({'a': [1, 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 5, 6, 6, 6], 'b':[1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 3, 3, 4]})
df.repetitions('b')

b
1    4
2    3
3    2
4    1
dtype: int64
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test(df.repetitions('b'), pd.Series({1:4, 2:3,3:2, 4:1}), all_equal)
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

DataFrame.repetition_counts[source]

DataFrame.repetition_counts(col)

Counts the number of groups with the same number of repetitions.

{% endraw %}

In the following example there are three groups with one element, two groups with two elements, and one group with three elements.

{% raw %} 
df.repetition_counts('a')

1    3
2    2
3    1
dtype: int64
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test(df.repetition_counts('a'), pd.Series({1: 3, 2:2, 3:1}), all_equal)
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

DataFrame.single_events[source]

DataFrame.single_events(col)

Returns rows that appear only once.

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df.single_events('a')
a b
0 1 1
1 2 1
2 3 1
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test_eq(df.single_events('a'), df.loc[[0, 1, 2]])
{% endraw %}

Functions as methods

Pandas functions that are easier to execute as DataFrame/Series methods.

{% raw %}

DataFrame.crosstab[source]

DataFrame.crosstab(index, column, values=None, rownames=None, colnames=None, aggfunc=None, margins:bool=False, margins_name:str='All', dropna:bool=True, normalize=False)

Compute a simple cross tabulation of two (or more) factors. By default computes a frequency table of the factors unless an array of values and an aggregation function are passed.

Parameters

index : array-like, Series, or list of arrays/Series Values to group by in the rows. columns : array-like, Series, or list of arrays/Series Values to group by in the columns. values : array-like, optional Array of values to aggregate according to the factors. Requires aggfunc be specified. rownames : sequence, default None If passed, must match number of row arrays passed. colnames : sequence, default None If passed, must match number of column arrays passed. aggfunc : function, optional If specified, requires values be specified as well. margins : bool, default False Add row/column margins (subtotals). margins_name : str, default 'All' Name of the row/column that will contain the totals when margins is True. dropna : bool, default True Do not include columns whose entries are all NaN. normalize : bool, {'all', 'index', 'columns'}, or {0,1}, default False Normalize by dividing all values by the sum of values.

- If passed 'all' or `True`, will normalize over all values.
- If passed 'index' will normalize over each row.
- If passed 'columns' will normalize over each column.
- If margins is `True`, will also normalize margin values.

Returns

DataFrame Cross tabulation of the data.

See Also

DataFrame.pivot : Reshape data based on column values. pivot_table : Create a pivot table as a DataFrame.

Notes

Any Series passed will have their name attributes used unless row or column names for the cross-tabulation are specified.

Any input passed containing Categorical data will have all of its categories included in the cross-tabulation, even if the actual data does not contain any instances of a particular category.

In the event that there aren't overlapping indexes an empty DataFrame will be returned.

Reference :ref:the user guide <reshaping.crosstabulations> for more examples.

Examples

a = np.array(["foo", "foo", "foo", "foo", "bar", "bar", ... "bar", "bar", "foo", "foo", "foo"], dtype=object) b = np.array(["one", "one", "one", "two", "one", "one", ... "one", "two", "two", "two", "one"], dtype=object) c = np.array(["dull", "dull", "shiny", "dull", "dull", "shiny", ... "shiny", "dull", "shiny", "shiny", "shiny"], ... dtype=object) pd.crosstab(a, [b, c], rownames=['a'], colnames=['b', 'c']) b one two c dull shiny dull shiny a bar 1 2 1 0 foo 2 2 1 2

Here 'c' and 'f' are not represented in the data and will not be shown in the output because dropna is True by default. Set dropna=False to preserve categories with no data.

foo = pd.Categorical(['a', 'b'], categories=['a', 'b', 'c']) bar = pd.Categorical(['d', 'e'], categories=['d', 'e', 'f']) pd.crosstab(foo, bar) col_0 d e row_0 a 1 0 b 0 1 pd.crosstab(foo, bar, dropna=False) col_0 d e f row_0 a 1 0 0 b 0 1 0 c 0 0 0

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

DataFrame.page[source]

DataFrame.page(page, page_size=5)

Shows rows from pagepage_size to (page+1)page_size

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df = pd.DataFrame({'a': range(15), 'b': range(15)})
df.page(2)
a b
5 5 5
6 6 6
7 7 7
8 8 8
9 9 9
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

Series.page[source]

Series.page(page, page_size=5)

Shows rows from pagepage_size to (page+1)page_size

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
s = pd.Series(range(15))
s.page(2)

5    5
6    6
7    7
8    8
9    9
dtype: int64
{% endraw %}

Method Variations

These methods are slight variations from DataFrame ones.

DataFrame.renamec[source]

DataFrame.renamec(d, *args)

Renames column names.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df = dummydf()
df.renamec({'col_1': 'col_a'}, 'col_2', 'bar')
col_a bar
0 100 a
1 101 b
2 102 c
3 103 d
4 104 e
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

DataFrame.less[source]

DataFrame.less(page_size=5, page=1, where=None)

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

DataFrame.to_percent[source]

DataFrame.to_percent(exclude=[])

Formats float columns to percentage.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df = pd.DataFrame({'a': range(17), 'b': range(17)})
df.less(page_size=7, page=2)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df.less(page_size=3, where=df.a.gt(5))
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

Series.less[source]

Series.less(page_size=5)

Displays one page of the Series and buttons to move forward and backward.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
s = pd.Series(range(7))
s.less()
{% endraw %}

{% endraw %} {% raw %}

DataFrame.c2front[source]

DataFrame.c2front(cols2front)

Move columns to front

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df = dummydf()
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df.c2back(['col_1'])
col_2 col_1
0 a 100
1 b 101
2 c 102
3 d 103
4 e 104
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df.c2back('col_1')
col_2 col_1
0 a 100
1 b 101
2 c 102
3 d 103
4 e 104
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df.c2front('col_2')
col_2 col_1
0 a 100
1 b 101
2 c 102
3 d 103
4 e 104
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df.c2front(['col_2'])
col_2 col_1
0 a 100
1 b 101
2 c 102
3 d 103
4 e 104
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

DataFrame.reorderc[source]

DataFrame.reorderc(sefl:DataFrame, to_front=[], to_back=[])

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df['col_3'] = df['col_1']
df.reorderc(['col_3'], ['col_1'])
col_3 col_2 col_1
0 100 a 100
1 101 b 101
2 102 c 102
3 103 d 103
4 104 e 104
